meanings.definition: To stray from the group or main path.
meanings.sent1: The little puppy would often straggle behind the rest of the litter during walks.
meanings.sent2: The hikers warned each other not to straggle and to stay together on the trail.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel decided to straggle off into the forest, playing a game of hide-and-seek.
meanings.sent4: Her thoughts would often straggle away from the task at hand, like leaves in the wind.
meanings.sent5: The lost child's cries for help echoed as he continued to straggle further from the group.

meanings.definition: To spread out in a disorderly way.
meanings.sent1: The toys would straggle across the room after the toddler's playtime.
meanings.sent2: The spilled marbles would straggle in all directions, making a mess on the floor.
meanings.sent3: The papers on the desk seemed to have a mind of their own, choosing to straggle instead of staying neat.
meanings.sent4: The vines in the garden would straggle and intertwine, creating a chaotic yet beautiful pattern.
meanings.sent5: The ants would straggle out of the cracked cookie jar, forming a disorderly line towards their nest.

meanings.definition: A person or thing that straggles.
meanings.sent1: The straggle at the back of the parade was a young child holding a colorful balloon.
meanings.sent2: The straggle of fallen leaves behind the rake made it clear where the gardener had missed.
meanings.sent3: The little duckling, the straggle of the group, waddled along at its own pace, quacking happily.
meanings.sent4: The lone straggle of clouds in the sky seemed to be lost, drifting aimlessly with no other clouds nearby.
meanings.sent5: The straggle of mismatched socks in the laundry basket seemed to have a secret meeting, waiting to be reunited.
